tit.e: Takenaka-mokuhan (a Japanese woodblock printing craft center)
Takenaka Mokuhan (a Japanese woodblock printing craft center)
tit.cmt: ハイフンを削除し Takenaka Mokuhan としました。
tit.e: Takenaka Mokuhan (a Japanese woodblock printing craft center)

sen.j: 竹中木版（たけなかもくはん 1884年創業）は、京都府京都市に工房を置く、日本の木版印刷工房。
sen.e: Takenaka-mokuhan is a craft center of Japanese woodblock printings, inaugurated in 1884, with a workshop located in Kyoto City, Kyoto Prefecture.
Takenaka Mokuhan is a craft center of Japanese woodblock printings, inaugurated in 1884, with a workshop located in Kyoto City, Kyoto Prefecture.
sen.cmt: ハイフンを削除し Takenaka Mokuhan としました。
sen.e: Takenaka Mokuhan is a craft center of Japanese woodblock printings, inaugurated in 1884, with a workshop located in Kyoto City, Kyoto Prefecture.
Its current head is Seihachi TAKENAKA.
Its current head is Seihachi TAKENAKA.
Its current head is Seihachi TAKENAKA.
Summary:
Summary
sen.cmt: コロンを削除しました。
sen.e: Summary
This woodblock printing craft center was found in 1884,
This woodblock printing craft center was found in 1884.
sen.cmt: カンマ→ピリオドに変更しました。
sen.e: This woodblock printing craft center was found in 1884.

sen.j: 機械印刷が主流になる前は、木版による印刷が主流だった。
sen.e: In the printing industry, woodblock printing had been predominant before machine printing became the major stream.
In the printing industry, woodblock printing had been predominant before machine printing became the major stream.
In the printing industry, woodblock printing had been predominant before machine printing became the major stream.

sen.j: その当時より代々技術を継承してきたのが竹中木版。
sen.e: Since the age of woodblock printing, the printing technology of Takenaka-mokuhan has been inherited from generation to generation.
Since the age of woodblock printing, the printing technique has been inherited from generation to generation.
sen.cmt: ハイフンを削除し Takenaka Mokuhan としました。Technology→ technique としました。
sen.e: Since the age of woodblock printing, the printing technique has been inherited from generation to generation.

sen.j: 現在6代目まで継承されている。
sen.e: Now, the technology is maintained in the center under the management of the sixth head.
At present, the technique has been handed down to the sixth head.
At present, the technique has been handed down to the sixth head.

sen.j: 京都には神社仏閣または、老舗の店舗が多いため、古い版木が現存している。
sen.e: In Kyoto, there are many shrines, temples and age-old stores, among which time-honored woodblock printers have existed.
In Kyoto, there are many shrines, temples and age-old stores, among which time-honored printing blocks have existed.
sen.cmt: 版木→printing block としました。
sen.e: In Kyoto, there are many shrines, temples and age-old stores, among which time-honored printing blocks have existed.

sen.j: その古い版木を、復刻・修復している、数少ない木版印刷工房である。
sen.e: Takenaka-mokuhan is one of such printers, though quite a few existing, as are engaged in reprinting and restoring of old printing blocks.
Takenaka Mokuhan is one of the few printers that are engaged in reprinting and restoring those old printing blocks.
sen.cmt: 一部翻訳を変更しました。
sen.e: Takenaka Mokuhan is one of the few printers that are engaged in reprinting and restoring those old printing blocks.

tit.cmt: コロンを削除しました。

sen.e: The fourth head, Seihachi TAKENAKA
The fourth head, Seihachi TAKENAKA
The fourth head, Seihachi TAKENAKA
The fifth head, Kenji TAKENAKA
The fifth head, Kenji TAKENAKA
The fifth head, Kenji TAKENAKA
The sixth head, Yuko HARADA
The sixth head, Yuko HARADA
The sixth head, Yuko HARADA

tit.cmt: コロンを削除しました。

sen.j: 「孔雀明王像」（木版画）仁和寺所蔵
sen.e: "Kujaku Myoo-zo"(literally "an image of Peacock King") which is a woodblock print possessed by Ninna-ji Temple.
Kujaku Myoo-zo (an image of Peacock King) (a woodblock print), possessed by Ninna-ji Temple
sen.cmt: 文頭に来るシングルクォーテーションを削除しました。一部語順を変更しました。
sen.e: Kujaku Myoo-zo (an image of Peacock King) (a woodblock print), possessed by Ninna-ji Temple

sen.j: 「狐釣の図」歌麿（浮世絵木版画）風の博物館所蔵
sen.e: "Kitsunetsuri-no-zu" (literally "an image of trapping a fox"), which is a woodblock print of Ukiyoe picture drawn by Utamaro, currently possessed by Kaze-no-Hakubutsukan (Wind Museum).
Kitsunetsuri-no-zu (an image of trapping a fox) drawn by Utamaro (a woodblock print of Ukiyo-e picture), currently possessed by Kaze-no-Hakubutsukan (Wind Museum)
sen.cmt: 文頭に来るシングルクォーテーションを削除しました。一部語順を変更しました。
sen.e: Kitsunetsuri-no-zu (an image of trapping a fox) drawn by Utamaro (a woodblock print of Ukiyo-e picture), currently possessed by Kaze-no-Hakubutsukan (Wind Museum)

sen.j: 「蹴鞠の図」歌麿（浮世絵木版画）渡辺美術館所蔵
sen.e: "Kemari-no-zu" (literally "an image of playing Kemari game", which is a woodblock print of Ukiyoe picture drawn by Utamaro, currently possessed by Watanabe Museum.
Kemari-no-zu (an image of playing Kemari game) drawn by Utamaro (a woodblock print of Ukiyo-e picture), currently possessed by Watanabe Museum
sen.cmt: 文頭に来るシングルクォーテーションを削除しました。一部語順を変更しました。
sen.e: Kemari-no-zu (an image of playing Kemari game) drawn by Utamaro (a woodblock print of Ukiyo-e picture), currently possessed by Watanabe Museum
